question: A horizontal pipe carries water in a streamlined flow. At a point along the pipe, where the cross-sectional area is <katex>$10\text{ cm}^2$</katex>, the velocity of water is <katex>$1\text{ ms}^{-1}$</katex> and the pressure is 2000 Pa. What is the pressure of water at another point where the cross-sectional area is <katex>$5\text{ cm}^2$</katex>? [Density of water <katex>$=1000\text{ kgm}^{-3}$</katex>]
explanation: By continuity equation: <katex>$A_1 v_1 = A_2 v_2 \implies 10(1) = 5(v_2) \implies v_2 = 2\text{ ms}^{-1}$</katex>.
By Bernoulli's principle: <katex>$P_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = P_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2$</katex>.
